title: What on TV tonight : Daisy May and Charlie Cooper NightWatch , Strictly Come Dancing and more
body_text:
What’s on TV tonight: Once Upon a Time in Space, IT: Welcome to Derry, and more
From new Apple TV series Down Cemetery Road (adapted from a novel by Slow Horses’ Mick Herron), to Mortimer & Whitehouse returning for more fishing, to the fantastic documentary Once Upon a Time in Space and Liam Hemsworth replacing Henry Cavill on The Witcher, here’s what to look forward to, and catch up on, this week.
What’s on TV tonight?
Once Upon a Time in Space
BBC Two, 9pm; all episodes will be available on iPlayer today
The historical Once Upon a Time documentaries of filmmaker James Bluemel are more interested in humanity than didacticism. Previously, Bluemel has used his vivid oral history approach to tell the story of the Iraq War and the Troubles in Northern Ireland; not just in terms of what happened, but how it felt to live through it. In this fascinating four-part follow-up he does the same for space: humanising the history of space exploration through astronauts, cosmonauts and the loved ones they left behind.
The focus of tonight’s opening episode is not the 1969 moon landing but the expansion of the Nasa space program in the 1970s. This is the period in which astronauts such as Ronald McNair made history by becoming one of the first black Americans in space. “From slavery to space in four generations,” recalls his brother Carl, emotional. Another key figure is astronaut Anna Lee Fisher, who received widespread criticism at the time for going to space as a mother. Sexism aside, says her daughter, Kristen, she does wonder if there is something inherently selfish about being an astronaut. A question brought into sharp relief by the 1986 Challenger disaster, which claimed the life of Ronald McNair.
b'
'
Robson Green: World’s Most Amazing Walks
U&Yesterday, 8pm; all episodes will be available on U today
This gentle eight-part travelogue follows earnest actor Robson Green as he enjoys some of the world’s most beautiful walks. He begins tonight with a stroll alongside Hadrian’s Wall; a personal favourite of Green’s that has been soured by the felling of the tree at the Sycamore Gap.
Blue Lights
BBC One, 9pm; all episodes are already available on iPlayer
Tonight’s penultimate episode of the sublime Northern Ireland crime drama features a nerve-shredding scene in which a seemingly mundane piece of policing turns into a frantic blood-soaked nightmare. The best part? The paramedic for whom this is all just another day.
The Forsytes
Channel 5, 9pm
The second week of the glossy period drama finds Jolyon (Danny Griffin) and Soames (Joshua Orpin) at odds over the ethics of an investment in India. More pressing, however, is Jolyon’s charged confrontation with Louise (Eleanor Tomlinson) and Soames’s desperate proposal to Millie Gibson’s Irene.
Jimmy Carr’s Am I the A**hole?
Comedy Central, 9pm
Not even the hosting talents of Jimmy Carr can salvage this lifeless panel show. It is based on a popular Reddit community in which people tell a colourful story and ask if they are in the wrong. Tonight’s panel judges are influencer GK Barry and comedian Jamali Maddix. You can also watch it on Paramount+ from tomorrow.
IT: Welcome to Derry
Sky Atlantic/NOW, 9pm
This gruesome eight-part prequel tells the story leading up to 2017 horror movie It, an adaptation of Stephen King’s classic novel. Bill Skarsgård reprises his role as Pennywise (the killer clown) although takes a backseat tonight for a tale about a group of 1960s kids tormented by a demon baby. SK
What’s on TV this week?
Saturday 25 October
Michael McIntyre’s The Wheel
BBC One/iPlayer, 8.20pm
There have been eight other versions of The Wheel around the world, yet none have made it beyond two series. As the British iteration begins its sixth run, what is its secret? For one, it has in Michael McIntyre a perfect host: bumptious and sympathetic, family friendly and a tad risqué – someone as ready to prick eminent egos as he is to lift the spirits of contestants fearing the worst. The lack of self-consciousness and celebrities genuinely invested in helping people win life-changing sums also helps – everyone is relaxed about being silly or, when the stakes are high, deadly serious.
Tonight sees a huge cash prize, engaging backstories (there are tears within the first five minutes), surely the best-received mention of Bobby Brown since the early 1990s and a long debate over the perfect cup of tea. The mix-and-match of famous faces remains as canny as ever, with Katherine Ryan, Susan Wokoma, Jill Scott, Layton Williams, Roman Kemp, Steve Pemberton and Reece Shearsmith all making their mark alongside, with doleful wit familiar to fans of Celebrity Traitors, Joe Marler. Only 10 questions are asked over the hour, yet the energy never flags.
b'
'
Live International Rugby League: England vs Australia
BBC One/iPlayer, 2pm
After 22 years, the Ashes return to Rugby League with a three-match series kicking off this afternoon at 2.30pm at Wembley Stadium. With Australia the world champions, they will be strong favourites to triumph once again and continue a series-winning streak dating back to 1970.
Live Women’s International Football: England vs Brazil
ITV1/ITVX, 4.45pm
It is hard to imagine Sarina Wiegman consenting to this week’s friendlies for the Lionesses being dubbed a “homecoming series”, with all the hubris that implies after this summer’s triumphs. Rest assured, England will be taking Brazil and Australia (whom England play on Tuesday, with coverage from 6.15pm on ITV4) very seriously, with the Seleção – like England – once again continental champions. Kick-off is at 5.30pm.
More in Entertainment
Whoopi Goldberg struggles to sit at “The View” table during painful discussion: 'I'm out'
Strictly Come Dancing
BBC One/iPlayer, 6.20pm
It’s Icons Week and, following the elimination of a third leaden-footed bloke, Chris Robshaw, plus the loss of Stefan Dennis via injury, our dancers will be paying tribute to musical legends running the gamut from the Beatles to Taylor Swift.
5 Days That Brought Down Prince Andrew
Channel 5, 9.20pm
After years of scandal and speculation of bad conduct, and with the recent publication of Virginia Giuffre’s memoir, Prince Andrew agreed to stop using his royal titles. This documentary assesses the events that led up to the downfall of the King’s brother, who still “vigorously” denies the accusations.
Nine Bodies in a Mexican Morgue
BBC One, 9.20pm; all episodes are already available on iPlayer
Anthony Horowitz’s enjoyably bonkers thriller approaches its denouement with federal agencies joining the search for the plane and its survivors, whose numbers are dwindling. GT
Sunday 26 October
Daisy May and Charlie Cooper’s NightWatch
BBC Two, 9pm; all episodes will be available on iPlayer today
Kicking off Hallowe’en week, siblings Daisy May and Charlie Cooper – who brought us the groundbreaking and hugely popular mockumentary This Country in 2017 – reunite for a new series in which they set out on a nationwide ghost hunt. They embark on a series of sleepovers in Britain’s most supposedly haunted places to see if anything, anything at all, happens in their quest for ghouls, spooks and scary apparitions.
Whether you find it funny will greatly depend on if you enjoy their company as much as they do each other’s, on the cusp of their forties now and still joshing and spatting endlessly in full-on brother-and-sister mode. In tonight’s opener, they stay fairly close to home, heading to Gloucester Prison, which has long since shut its doors to the living. But it has a reputation for strong paranormal activity thanks to a 300-year history of incarcerating some of Britain’s most notorious criminals (Fred West among them), and with many of those who died or were executed there buried in the grounds. Not exactly a recipe for a restful night’s sleep in a tiny bunk-bed cell, especially when there’s an emergency fake-tan session to fit in as well.
Mayor of Kingstown
Paramount+
Taylor Sheridan and Hugh Dillon’s gritty US crime drama returns for a fourth season. Now that Kingstown is finally free of the Russian mafia, Mike’s (Jeremy Renner) control comes under a new threat as competing rivals pile in to fill the power vacuum, sparking yet another bloody gang war. New episodes will arrive weekly.
Guy Martin: The British Train that Changed the World
Channel 4, 7.30pm
Celebrating the 200th anniversary of one of Britain’s great engineering achievements, Guy Martin joins a team building a replica of the locomotive that pulled the first passenger train along the Stockton and Darlington railway and retraces the 26-mile journey that sparked a boom in rail travel.
BBC Cardiff Singer of the World: A Celebration Concert
BBC Four/iPlayer, 7.30pm
Gareth Malone and Danielle de Niese host a concert featuring previous winners and finalists from the internationally renowned singing competition. With performances from, among others, Natalya Romaniw, Catriona Morison, Ilker Arcayürek and Andrei Bondarenko.
Mortimer & Whitehouse: Gone Fishing
BBC Two, 9pm; all episodes will be available on iPlayer today
Embarking on an eighth run, Bob Mortimer and Paul Whitehouse’s thoughtful series has lost none of its charm yet taken on the familiarity of a pair of comfy old slippers. Here, as a birthday treat for Paul, they pitch up at one of the great fly-fishing chalk-stream rivers, the Itchen in Hampshire, hoping to hook some wild brown trout.
Trigger Point
ITV1, 9pm; all episodes will be available on ITVX today
Vicky McClure returns in Jed Mercurio’s explosive drama about a team of bomb disposal experts battling trigger mechanisms and terrorism on the streets of London. Tonight, Lana (McClure) endures a traumatic opening episode when a lone-wolf bomber starts targeting individuals in what appears to be a personal vendetta. GO
Tuesday 28 October
Mary at 90: a Lifetime of Cooking
BBC Two, 7.30pm
“People need to be reminded of old favourites,” says Dame Mary Berry while rustling up a cottage pie, although she could just as easily be talking about herself. Perhaps she is. Berry, often characterised as rather prim and proper and admitting herself that “once a girl guide, always a girl guide”, has a sense of mischief that can go underappreciated.
Her first guest in this new series is Tom Allen (Alan Titchmarsh, Gabby Logan and Kiell Smith-Bynoe are among those appearing later), who brings that out in spades – or spoons, at least – as they discuss tarts and peaks while boating down the Thames. The premise is “making new memories with good friends”, which means watching a few old clips (Judith Chalmers pops up regularly) and updating some classic recipes with ingredients newer to Berry: samphire, lime leaves, lemongrass.
Tonight, alongside the aforementioned cottage pie with a twist, we get a Thai chicken traybake, pan-fried cod and bread and butter pudding, each eminently replicable and mouthwateringly presented, never sacrificing flavour for approachability. Whatever her tenth decade may hold, this is a celebration as low-key, classy and fun as its subject.
The Great British Bake Off
Channel 4, 8pm
The four remaining bakers face Patisserie Week in a semi-final of cream horns, sugar glass domes and, as a showstopper, a sculpture of macarons.
Battle Treasures with Foxy and Bruce
Sky History/NOW, 8.30pm
Former SAS man Jason Fox and historian Bruce Crompton join forces for this enjoyably granular, occasionally bloodthirsty new series about historical artefacts and their connections to modern warfare. They begin with an examination of assault rifles.
The Good Life: Inside Out
U&Gold, 9pm
Penelope Keith introduces another of U&Gold’s excellent sitcom retrospectives, with contributions from co-stars (Richard Briers and Paul Eddington from archive footage, of course) as well as assorted writers and producers. Strange now to recall it was a critical and commercial slow starter, but by the time of its boldly downbeat farewell, The Good Life was a lynchpin of British TV comedy – so much so that Elizabeth II was treated to her own bespoke episode a year later.
Welded Together: Storyville
BBC Four/iPlayer, 10pm
Rounding off another exceptional run of Storyvilles, this Belarusian documentary offers an unflinching depiction of generational trauma. Katya, a young welder, reconnects with her troubled mother and infant half-sister: a fulfilling, supportive working life is contrasted with the domestic chaos of addiction and abandonment, to potent effect.
In My Own Words: Tom Jones
BBC One/iPlayer, 10.40pm
Sir Tom Jones is by turns tickled and moved to have his memory jogged in this lovely film. While the arc might by now be familiar – working-class upbringing in the Welsh Valleys, discovery of that extraordinary voice, 1960s stardom, television, Elvis and Vegas, knicker-hurling self-parody and unlikely comebacks – Jones remains a fine and perceptive raconteur. GT
Wednesday 29 October
Down Cemetery Road
Apple TV
Apple’s Slow Horses adaptations of Mick Herron’s Slough House spy novels are among the greatest glories of the TV-streaming era. And as series five comes to an entertainingly edge-of-seat conclusion today, a starry new adaptation of another Herron novel lands. With Apple-sized budgets, a cast led by Emma Thompson and Ruth Wilson, and a scriptwriter, Morwenna Banks, who’s already a name, success seems all but guaranteed.
Even so, this was Herron’s debut novel, and the first in the early years series of Zoe Boehm (Thompson) detective stories he wrote long before Jackson Lamb was a gleam in his authorial eye. So, while it clearly has Herron’s distinctive style and humour running through it like a stick of rock, it doesn’t always gel. Especially with a cast of well-known supporting actors who seem too keen to let us know they’re in on the joke.
By the end of today’s opening pair of episodes, though, it’s shaken off most of those jitters and keeping us nicely gripped as Wilson, in the role of not-to-be-deterred Sarah Tucker, employs the services of Oxford’s least promising private detective agency to investigate, following a deadly house explosion on her street.
b'
'
The Crash Detectives
BBC Two/BBC One Wales/iPlayer, 7pm
In Caerphilly, the race is on to investigate why a rider lost control of a powerful motorbike and crashed into a wall on a quiet residential street. And in Chepstow, the air ambulance is called in for a woman seriously injured when the car she was travelling in collided with a stationary lorry.
Portrait Artist of the Year 2025
Sky Arts/NOW, 8pm
It’s fascinating to see how differently each artist approaches their subject in this always-entrancing competition. In tonight’s fifth heat, Emily Attack, Melvin Odoom and Max Beesley are the trio of high-profile sitters waiting to see how the latest batch of qualifiers recreates them on canvas.
The Celebrity Traitors
BBC One/iPlayer, 9pm
With barely more than a handful of players left in the game, and just two more episodes to go after this, the Traitors are under as much pressure as the Faithful to get the next Round Table right. First, though, there’s a seriously challenging mission to get through.
Grand Designs
Channel 4, 9pm
You can see the mischievous gleam in Kevin McCloud’s eyes when tonight’s self-builders tell him they want to build a giant 21st-century castle, complete with tower, castellations, a moat, arrow slits, courtyards and futuristic technology throughout. And they want to have it listed. Even with a budget of £2.2 million, surely that can’t all go according to plan, can it?
David Hare Remembers... The Absence of War
BBC Four/iPlayer, 10pm
Playwright David Hare recalls adapting his 1993 play The Absence of War, a thinly veiled critique of Labour leader Neil Kinnock’s failure to oust the Conservative government in the 1992 general election, for the BBC’s Screen Two strand. John Thaw, in a widely acclaimed performance, plays the lead in the adaptation which follows at 10.15pm. GO
Thursday 30 October
The Witcher
Netflix
The fourth series of Netflix’s gory fantasy epic opens with a child telling the story of Geralt of Rivia, the superhuman monster hunter who is known as a Witcher. It is ostensibly a recap, but the intention is to reintroduce the character with a new face. Up until now, Geralt was played by Superman star Henry Cavill. In 2022, however, Cavill stepped away from the role after reportedly disagreeing with how the show was adapting the books of Polish author Andrzej Sapkowski. To much fan grumbling online, the part has since been recast with The Hunger Games’ Liam Hemsworth.
The transition takes getting used to. The soft-faced Hemsworth plays Geralt with the same growl as Cavill, but is an altogether gentler take on the character. A direction that befits a warrior who Sapkowski writes as being more sensitive than his rugged, brutish persona. Be warned, though: Geralt’s recasting is not an invitation for new viewers to hop on board. Today’s eight episodes pick up directly after the third series’ finale – with Geralt on his way to the evil kingdom of Nilfgaard to save his adopted daughter Ciri (Freya Allan) – and its fantasy world is as dense and impenetrable as ever.
b'
'
Aileen: Queen of the Serial Killers
Netflix
Between 1989 and 1990, Aileen Wuornos murdered seven men across central Florida – a killing spree that ended with the electric chair. This disturbing true crime documentary uses never-before-seen death row interviews with Wuornos to stitch together the story of both what she did and why she did it.
Brassic
Sky Max/NOW, 2am & 10pm
This anarchic comedy about a group of northern ne’er-do-wells has become one of Sky’s biggest hits. It reaches its end tonight with a swaggering blood-soaked finale; in which Joe Gilgun’s lovable rogue Vinnie attempts to broker a truce between two psychopathic gangsters in a carvery.
Inside The Tower of London
Channel 5, 8pm
Tonight’s return of the long-running Tower of London documentary series follows the preparations for last year’s commemoration of the 80th anniversary of D-Day. The jewel in the occasion’s crown is organiser Debbie Whittingham’s poignant idea to have a lone bagpiper perform the haunting lament that echoed across the beaches on D-Day.
Art Detectives
U&Drama, 8pm
We have had crosswords, books and antiques, so why not a cosy murder mystery about art? This passable six-part romp follows the Heritage Crime Unit’s detective Mick Palmer (Stephen Moyer, who’s also currently appearing in The Forsytes on Channel 5) as he solves unusual culture-themed mysteries. Such as tonight’s brutal murder of an art historian.
All Creatures Great and Small
Channel 5, 9pm
The sixth series of the soothing veterinary drama comes to an end tonight with momentous news: Japan has surrendered; the Second World War is over. For Callum Woodhouse’s soldier Tristan, however, the war cannot be folded away so easily. As illustrated by his triggering encounter with a shire horse. SK
Friday 31 October
Return to Paradise
BBC One/iPlayer, 8pm
The second series of the soapy police drama set in Australia – part of the global Death in Paradise universe – begins the day after the first series ended; Mackenzie “Mack” Clarke (Anna Samson) is still in her hometown of Dolphin Cove, after failing to return to her life and job in London. She decided to stay after overhearing her ex-fiancé Glenn (Tai Hara) – whom she jilted at the altar – saying he still has feelings for her. But she can’t pluck up the courage to tell him and now they find themselves working together again – she as a detective, he as a forensic scientist, with matters further complicated by Glenn planning his wedding to Daisy (Andrea Demetriades). So a will-they-won’t-they storyline is neatly set up for the series, plus a potential love triangle.
The crime-solving element in this opening episode of six concerns the death of a scientist working at a groundbreaking shark research lab, who is found dead alone on a boat – was it an accident or, as Mack suspects, a murder? She has to prove it – and Glenn and sidekick Colin (Lloyd Griffith) help to find the killer. Ardal O’Hanlon makes a guest appearance as Mack’s boss back in the UK.
b'
'
Unreported World
Channel 4, 7.30pm
Guillermo Galdos reports for the documentary strand from Colombia, where rival anti-government militias who control the cocaine trade have brought the country to a state of violent conflict again. Civilians face a daily threat of killings, forced recruitment and displacement.
Borderline
ITV1, 9pm; all episodes are already available on ITVX
This engaging policier is much helped by the odd-couple dynamic between the two leads – steady hand PSNI DCI Boyd (Eoin Macken) and the Garda’s sparky DI Regan (Amy De Bhrún) – as they solve cases that straddle the Northern Ireland border. In this first of a two-parter, a hurling star is murdered and their investigation uncovers a gambling and prostitution ring. Meanwhile, both officers’ past lives – personal and professional – crash into their present.
Sister Boniface Mysteries
U&Drama, 9pm
Another enjoyably daft whodunnit; the Great Slaughter team are taking part in a team-building exercise against local rivals Stowington Police when one of Stowington’s members is murdered. Sister Boniface (Lorna Watson) starts sleuthing to help DI Sam Gillespie (Max Brown) and his colleagues find the culprit.
How Are You? It’s Alan (Partridge)
BBC One, 9.30pm; all episodes are already available on iPlayer
The excellent comedy continues as the newly single Alan – “There were signs; we stopped tickling each other” – throws himself into fresh experiences to see if they can boost his mental health. As ever Felicity Montagu and Tim Key give great support to Steve Coogan’s cringe-making Alan.
The Walking Dead: Daryl Dixon
Sky Max/NOW, 10pm
After a slow start, the third series of the apocalyptic drama gathers pace; after the shipwreck Daryl (Norman Reedus) and Carol (Melissa McBride) are now in Spain – and find themselves in the middle of a war between surviving factions. VL
Television previewers
Stephen Kelly (SK), Veronica Lee (VL), Gerard O’Donovan (GO), Vicki Power (VP) and Gabriel Tate (GT)
